title: Prefigurative Community Building (Part 4): Growing Power With - Democratic Food Co-ops
summary: How to start a democratic food co-op without Power Over dynamics. A comprehensive guide to building community-owned grocery stores that center transparency, sustainability, and shared decision-making.

Money.summary: Create democratic, community-owned alternatives to corporate food systems.

level0: Gather core circle of 3-6 people with shared trust and values
Define collective intention for why you're starting the co-op
level1: Start with bulk-buying club to practice governance
Learn from existing co-ops and food justice groups
level2: Build shared infrastructure using non-hierarchical structure
Incorporate as cooperative with democratic governance
level3: Establish full-scale food co-op with community ownership
Help other communities start their own co-ops

Food.summary: Democratize access to ethical, local, and culturally relevant food.

level0: Research ethical suppliers and local farms
Practice bulk ordering with small group
level1: Stock culturally relevant and locally grown foods
Accept EBT and offer sliding scale memberships
level2: Build relationships with urban farms and mutual aid groups
Create transparent pricing and markup policies
level3: Become food sovereignty hub connecting multiple food justice projects

Community.summary: Build shared ownership and democratic participation in essential services.

level0: Use consensus or sociocratic methods for all decisions
Rotate logistics roles to avoid centralizing power
level1: Create onboarding rituals that pass on culture and values
level2: Expand participation while maintaining horizontal structure
Partner with schools, tenant unions, and mutual aid groups
level3: Model democratic economics for broader community transformation

Knowledge.summary: Learn cooperative development while sharing democratic organizing skills.

level0: Learn about cooperative legal structures and governance
Study successful food co-ops and their practices
level1: Develop skills in facilitation and consensus decision-making
Learn financial transparency and democratic management
level2: Teach others about cooperative economics and food justice
level3: Become resource for cooperative development in your region
